business.start.para: The PRESIDENT(Senator the Hon. Margaret Reid) took the chair at 2.00 p.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Parer representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Can the minister confirm that in a media release entitled `Government Announces Pig Industry Assistance' dated 10 June the government announced it intended to `correct a surprising administrative anomaly' by introducing a general safeguard mechanism into the relevant legislation? Does the government still intend to take this action? If not, why not? If so, when will the government act?

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: —I do recall words to that effect in a press release put out, I think, by the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and also the Deputy Prime Minister. The government has moved to address all aspects of a Senate resolution of 7 April calling for action under World Trade Organisation rules—and I think that is what it referred to—on the effects of imports on the pig industry in particular. On 10 June it announced, as you would be aware, a further package of financial assistance to the industry, amounting to another $9 million for investment grants to specialist pig processors. It has also set aside special provisions under the national component of the new FarmBis scheme to improve risk management skills and the adoption of best practice in the industry.

answer.para: The government has also announced a benchmarking study of the entire pork production processing and supply catch to assess performance of the industry. It identified the need for a study of the medium-term export opportunities focusing on Asia. The minister welcomes the finalisation on 26 June of the terms of the reference from the Treasurer to the Productivity Commission for an inquiry into the imports of uncooked pork and into the profitability and competitiveness of the pig farming and pig meat processing indus tries. This inquiry will examine whether safeguard action is warranted against imports of frozen pig meat under the WTO safeguards arrangements and will report within 140 days. It is now up to the industry to convince the Productivity Commission that the safeguard measures on imports of frozen pork can be justified under the WTO.

The Deputy Prime Minister has also indicated that the government would lead a high level trade mission to key markets in order to expand opportunities for exports of Australian pig meat in the latter half of 1998. This assistance is over and above that which the minister announced in November 1997 for the provision of $10 million in assistance to the pig industry under the national pork industry development program. In addition, on 8 April 1998 the government introduced amendments to the Trade Practices Act to clarify claims of `Product of Australia' and `Made in Australia'. I believe these are currently before the Senate or will be in the next few days.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, isn't it true that the press release said, `The previous Labor government inexplicably failed to include such a safeguard mechanism in legislation introduced to the Parliament'—not something to do with World Trade Organisation rules? Doesn't the minister agree that the claim that legislative amendments were required was no more than a delaying tactic by the government?

question.para: In relation to the Productivity Commission report and the request that it report in 140 days, doesn't this mean that the government has effectively deferred any decision to protect producers from a flood of imports until after the next federal election? Isn't this yet another example of the minister for primary industries and the minister for trade putting the interests of rural Australia last?

talker.name: Parer, Sen Warwick
Senator PARER
talker.role: Resources and Energy

talk.start.para: —The answer to most of those questions is no. The government has acted very quickly with regard to the pig industry. It recognises—and I think I have said this a number of times in this place—and has great concern about the difficulties facing the pig industry. A lot of it has to do with things like oversupply of pork—not just with in Australia but around the world. But the point is made that the inquiry will examine whether safeguard action is warranted against imports of frozen pig meat under the WTO safeguards agreement. With respect to the balance of the question on legislation, I will refer that to the minister.

—My question is to Senator Ellison as the minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, and relates to the government's Jobs Network initiative. Is it a fact that while Labor was in office nearly one million people were out of work—to say nothing of many times that number who were underemployed—that nearly 360,000 Australians were unemployed for 12 months or longer, and that the only thing the Labor government did for them was dream up taxpayer funded make work programs like Working Nation? Didn't they shuttle them between the Department of Social Security and the Commonwealth Employment Service and provide no focus at all for them to get jobs? I ask the Minister how the government's new program, the Jobs Network initiative, is addressing these shortcomings.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Schools, Vocational Education and Training

talk.start.para: —There is no doubt that long-term unemployment is one of the most serious social problems that this country faces. It has ramifications in both the personal and societal senses in that it tears apart our social fabric, and there is also an economic consequence. This is a very important problem which this government is addressing and one which the former government obviously did not address.

answer.para: Under the current Leader of the Opposition, Kim Beazley, when he was minister for employment, there were 359,000 long- term unemployed people. Indeed, in December 1992, when he was the minister, unemployment peaked at 11.2 per cent. His comments back in 1993 when he was minister for employment illustrated Labor's attitude to the long-term unemployed. I quote from Hansard:
What we are going to live with, and what they are living with, is going to be a very lengthy period of unemployment for some people . . .

I am proud to say that this coalition government has not succumbed to this defeatist attitude which dominated the Leader of the Opposition when he was the minister for employment. We are addressing the question of long-term unemployment. Today, there are 123,000 fewer long-term unemployed people.

With the Jobs Network, we are providing choice and convenience for unemployed people. Obviously, the opposition does not want to hear this, but in the former system you had to go to the CES and be registered as unemployed. You then had to go to the Department of Social Security to collect your payment. What we are providing today in this reform is 1,400 sites—over four times the 296 sites offered by the CES previously.

But what does the opposition do? The opposition is content to pick out the negatives, to nitpick and to downgrade this reform for those seeking employment. The Ballarat Community Education Centre had this to say:
The Federal Government's new Jobs Network system is working extremely well and negative comments are both inconsistent with reality and damaging to the new scheme.
Jobs Australia said this:

It was unfortunate that media coverage of the new Jobs Network arrangements has generally focused on the negative and that stories about smooth and successful operations and positive outcomes for unemployed people do not get the attention they deserve.

That is what job providers are saying. Jobs Australia is an association of 40 community groups dealing with those people who need intensive assistance. The opposition would do well to listen, because this is what it is all about. These people are involved at the coalface and they are saying this system is working. Yet the opposition is still nitpicking, going on with all the negatives, breeding a feeling of despair and despondency, and misleading those unemployed Australians.

Jobs Network has already, after eight weeks of operation, provided thousands of jobs to job seekers. About 40,000 have been lodged on the national vacancy database. There is a telephone number—13 17 15—which any employer can ring to lodge a vacancy at no cost. That is available to all job seekers. Jobs Power in Victoria said:
Our recent experience has confirmed that the system is reliable and operating well . . .
The opposition would do well to listen to these positive comments. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. Has the minister verified the reports which the opposition drew to her attention last week that banks were charging extra fees in cases where benefits were paid late as a result of Centrelink error? Is the minister aware that Centrelink in Western Australia has agreed to refund $80 in bank charges to a couple on benefits who were forced to pay these charges as a consequence of a late payment from Centrelink? Will the minister now give an undertaking that all those in similar situations will receive refunds?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Social Security

talk.start.para: —There is an arrangement whereby people who suffer from defective administration in Commonwealth agencies can be reimbursed. Every case, however, is considered on its individual merits, and that would be the case in these circumstances.

—I have a supplementary question, Madam President. The couple in question got their compensation because they went to their local Labor member of parliament. Will the minister give an undertaking that all those who incur charges as a result of late payments by Centrelink will be compensated? Will she ensure that they all get compensated for the costs they have incurred?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Social Security

talk.start.para: —I suggest that constituents who have had this problem—and there have been very few of them, I am glad to say—might do well to cut out the middleman and go straight back to Centrelink.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Social Security. The minister has previously outlined the many benefits associated with the introduction of the youth allowance, including rent assistance for students and a more generous means test than currently operates. The previous Labor government had a policy to pay young people more to be on the dole rather than to continue in education or training programs. Could the minister outline the government's changes to youth payments, addressing Labor's failures, particularly its failure to assist students with rent assistance?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Social Security

talk.start.para: —I am very grateful for the question because one of the most important reforms to benefit young people is to be introduced tomorrow. The opposition has struggled mightily over the last few weeks with their friends in the CPSU to try to develop a campaign to somehow frighten people about the youth allowance. The reality is that, of the 560,000 young Australians who will be affected by the introduction of this allowance, 153,750 will receive more money, 361,200 will receive the same payment, 32,350 will receive a reduced payment and 12,800 will receive no money.

answer.para: The important point is that students who have been campaigning for years to get rent assistance to be able to afford to go away to study, to be able to afford to have a decent standard of living while they are studying, at last are getting rent assistance. They are not only getting rent assistance, but they are also getting a pharmaceutical allowance and, if they live in remote parts of Australia, they may also be eligible for a remote area allowance.

I think what the scare campaign of the opposition is refusing to recognise or acknowledge is that they had an Austudy parental means test which, in fact, is less generous than the parental means test which will apply from tomorrow. First of all, they both started at about the same number of dollars as a base but under youth allowance they cut out very much higher. For example, for a family with one child living at home, the cut-out point would be at $41,000—about $4,000 more than the cut-out point for Austudy. If there was one young person living away from home, then the cut-out point of the family income would be $58,000—that is $12,000 more than the cut-out point for Austudy. You are not hearing the Labor spokesman acknow ledging that as she travels around the country trying to frighten people.

The Labor spokesman is claiming that families in Gympie, Lismore, Burnie and Bendigo are going to somehow be disadvantaged by that. It just shows how out of touch the Labor Party still is because those are areas which, like most of rural and regional Australia, are still suffering after 13 years of Labor. These are families on low to middle incomes, compared with the rest of Australia. Most in fact will be eligible for assistance for their young people.

All we have had from the Labor Party is complaints about the initiative. Do they really want to go back to students getting less than the young unemployed? Are they prepared to go out and campaign in the next election on their cuts to the extra expenditure? This is not a savings measure, Madam President. It is $212 million extra expenditure on youth allowance—extra money over the next four years for youth allowance for the benefit of students as well as young people looking for work. But no, what we have got is a campaign of ALP and CPSU delegates trying to beat up a storm, trying to frighten the public, trying to do something to help the CPSU in its industrial relations campaign, in its negotiations of a new agreement with Centrelink management. Our staff are working very hard in Centrelink to get the information to young people and to process their applications. We have a new policy being implemented for a new—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Can the minister confirm that, contrary to claims by the government, the number of sites providing intensive assistance to the long-term unemployed—those most in need of assistance—has actually fallen under the Job Network program? Will the minister admit that the combined number of sites assisting the long-term unemployed under the CES contracted case managers model was approximately 860 whilst, now, only 700 sites are available to the long-term unemployed under the Job Network program?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Schools, Vocational Education and Training

talk.start.para: —It is well known that the referrals for intensive assistance have been very good, because what we have here is a system which has three—

—On a point of order, Madam President. We have had a number of occasions to observe how the Labor Party is conducting itself in question time today. On each occasion when a question has been asked of a minister, it has been followed by constant interruptions on the other side. I simply invite you to say that that is not acceptable conduct. Just because Senator Cook is still smarting from missing out on that job as a cleaner with the ILO, he wants to take it out on us all the time.
—Order! Senator Alston, you should stick to the point of order.
—It is not acceptable conduct and it is not a proper way of allowing question time to proceed.

—Madam President, on the point of order. This is the oldest tactic in the book—Senator Alston coming in to try to give Senator Ellison a bit of time to turn up the brief and get his confidence back, because we all know he has lost his confidence in question time. It is an abuse of question time, an abuse of procedure and an abuse of the standing orders and Senator Alston knows it, Madam President.
—Order! Your behaviour is outrageous and in breach of the standing orders.

—Madam President, on the point of order: the oldest trick in the book, which Senator Faulkner is aware of and practises on a daily basis, is for a minister to be asked a question and, precisely as outlined by Senator Alston, Senator Faulkner—with his back to you because he is too chicken to do it to your face; he is the sort of gutless little person that beat up kids behind the toilet block—

—You probably beat up kids behind the toilet block and pulled wings off butterflies. Too chicken to front up to the President and do it. And his little cohorts behind support him in the task of ensuring that ministers cannot concentrate on answering questions. That is the abuse of question time that is going on.

—Madam President, on the point of order. You may not have been able to hear it from down that end of the chamber but Senator Mackay had not even sat down on her seat before she started screeching across the chamber at Senator Ellison. Hansard will record a punctuation mark, if not a question mark, at the end of her question and, then, if they were to be accurate—if it is possible for the poor Hansard reporters—they will record a barrage of screeching before Senator Ellison had even stood on his feet. I would ask you to at least ask Senator Mackay to stop screeching. I would support Senator Vanstone in her submission to you to stop Senator Faulkner from turning his back to you—which I know you have asked him not to do before—and then, with his raucous voice, engaging in a continual commentary on question time. All Senator Faulkner is doing is trying to do the ABC commentators out of a job.

—Order! I think it would be better for everybody if we proceeded with question time and that most people—both inside and outside the chamber—be given the opportunity to hear the questions and the answers.
—Madam President, as I was saying—
—Before you were so rudely interrupted by Senator Alston.
—Order! Senators on my left will behave!

—We have three programs, basically job matching, job search assistance and intensive assistance. This has been provided through 1,400 job sites which is over four times the number of sites which were provided under the previous system. As I said earlier—and I do not know whether Senator Mackay was listening—we have referred 122,000 people for intensive assistance. I said that in my previous answer. That is just 3,000 short of our target of 125,000, which we are on target to meet by the end of this month.

answer.para: Those figures are very good figures indeed, because intensive assistance goes to your indigenous people, your migrants and your long-term unemployed. Remember the long-term unemployed, of which you had 359,000 when you were in government. We have cut that number by 123,000.

What we have here is an opposition that does not want to live up to the facts of the history when it was in government, when it presided over the worst unemployment figures in recent times. It does not want to look at a system which only had 296 job sites that unemployed people could go to. It does not want to acknowledge the fact that we have job providers who are saying, `We are getting people jobs. We are getting people who need intensive assistance. We are looking after those people.' We have 40,000 new jobs on the vacancy service. We have a free service where an employer can lodge a vacancy, the 13 17 15 phone line. That incurs no cost.

What we have here is a system which is going well, a system where job providers have said, `We're sick and tired of nit-picking.' The negativity is only going to breed despair. It is doing this reform a disservice, and the opposition needs to take account of itself in this regard because it does nothing for the unemployed people in this country—especially the long-term unemployed—when it keeps attacking this program.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it or is it not the case that there are now 160 fewer sites available to long-term unemployed people through intensive assistance? Isn't it true that long-term unemployment has risen by 4.5 per cent since the last election? Isn't it true that this rise will be further compounded by the government's failure to provide sufficient access points for long-term unemployed people to intensive assistance under the Jobs Network program? Isn't it true that this new system is everything to do with saving money—$1.8 billion to be exact—and nothing to do with providing services to long-term unemployed people?

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris
Senator ELLISON
talker.role: Schools, Vocational Education and Training

talk.start.para: —For each disadvantaged person who comes under the intensive assistance program, there is an up-front payment of over $1,500. That is the commitment that this government is providing. Senator Mackay asked whether this was a cost saving exercise. It is not. It is an endeavour to help those people who are long-term unemployed. We are putting the money up-front and the incentives are there for those people. More than 300 organisations are involved in the total Jobs Network program. We are offering more choice. We are offering them financial incentives. We are offering the reforms to get the long-term unemployed people back into the work force. That is what we are doing.

—My question is to the Minister for Social Security. Is the minister aware of reports that senior Centrelink staff have stated that, if data collection forms sent out to current Austudy recipients are not returned by 8 July, these students will be deemed to have breached their obligations and they will be docked 18 per cent of their benefits for six months? Is the minister aware of a letter sent by Senator Tambling to AYPAC this month which promises a publicity campaign emphasising the importance of returning the forms? It also promises two reminder letters and individual telephone calls to those who will be no longer eligible for payment or who will suffer a significant reduction. Minister, what has happened to the publicity campaign? Do you realise that there is nothing about the deadline or the penalties on the common youth allowance website and that the $3.8 million common youth allowance promotional campaign also fails to make any mention of these particular penalties?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Social Security

talk.start.para: —I have noticed that Senator Stott Despoja claimed some of these things in a press release that she put out, but I am afraid she did not pay much attention to accurate statements on this matter. She has an ideological position, I am afraid. The answer is that, no, young people who return the youth allowance data collection forms after 1 July will not be incurring a breach and have their payments reduced, although she claimed that in her press release.

answer.para: At this stage, I had better make clear something that I am very pleased about. Senator Stott Despoja mentioned the website. Maybe not every item that she wants is on the website but there is a great deal there. We have had 72,000 hits on the website in the five weeks since the site was established. So that is a pretty good indication that young people and their families are interested.

Let me get back to this question of breaches. An administrative breach is imposed only where a person refuses or fails to comply with the request for information without reasonable excuse. It is understandable that some young people may have had trouble getting the information required, even though they were sent the data collection form five weeks ago. Centrelink are therefore doing all they can to help, including phoning those who have not sent the forms back. I hope Senator Stott Despoja appreciates that personal service.

If young people do not send the form back, Centrelink cannot work out if they qualify for youth allowance, so payments will stop until such time as they return the form. Those who return their forms after 1 July will have payments completely restored, provided they are qualified. So I urge all young people who received a form to send it back as soon as possible or to go and talk to their Centrelink office if they are having trouble getting the necessary information. Some young people will have found work in the intervening weeks and will not be returning a form for that reason. Nevertheless, I urge those who have been sent a form to contact Centrelink so we can establish their eligibility or otherwise for existing or new payments.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, are you denying that senior Centrelink staff have said to student and youth organisations that 8 July is the deadline by which current Austudy recipients must have their forms into Centrelink or else they will incur a penalty of 18 per cent docked for six months from their common youth allowance? I am not talking about all common youth allowance applications that have to be in by 30 June. I understand those penalties, even though you have not advertised those as well. Is the minister denying that that is being said by Centrelink officials to current Austudy recipients? Will the minister give a guarantee that those people who do suffer a reduction in their benefits or some kind of breach will be reinstated and repaid those benefits?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Social Security

talk.start.para: —As to the last point, I think I made that perfectly clear in the answer I gave. I think Senator Stott Despoja should recognise that there are something like 24,000 employees in Centrelink, and I am not going to stand here and say that any one of them did or did not say anything in particular until I have had advice as to what can be ascertained from Centrelink. That would be commonsense surely. I would be interested to know this: if Senator Stott Despoja is claiming that senior officials in Centrelink said something about 8 July, why was it that she put 7 July in her press release?

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General, Senate Vanstone. Has the Attorney-General's Department been advised by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade of its concerns that the government's policy on the parallel importation of CDs could illegitimately allow the importation of pirate CDs into Australia?

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Justice

talk.start.para: —I thank the senator for her question. I do not have a brief at hand on that matter. I will make inquiries and get back to her.

—While you are there, has the Attorney-General's Department been advised by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade that the government's policy could also breach TRIPS and Australia's general obligations as a member of the World Trade Organisation? Does the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade's advice also suggest that an international challenge to the government's policy, if implemented, from either the US or the European Union is a realistic possibility?

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. That is clearly not a supple mentary question. There is no way that that could have arisen out of the answer that was given by Senator Vanstone. It is a second and, as it turned out, a third question. The opportunity is to ask one question and then you have an entitlement to ask something arising out of the answer. But that opportunity, in this instance, was not given to the honourable senator. She is abusing the standing orders by seeking to do it in a different way.

—On the point of order, Madam President: Senator Lundy asked Senator Vanstone whether advice had been given by one department and whether that advice was to a certain effect. The answer was that Senator Vanstone did not know, but Senator Lundy then went on to refer to the same advice from the same department and asked further whether in fact other points of concern were raised in respect of the same proposal. The supplementary question goes to the minister's state of knowledge about this particular brief. The minister may not have known about the first point raised, but she may very well have known about the second and third. It does relate to the same matter. It is fairly in order. The fact that the minister cannot answer it is obviously a matter of embarrassment for the government and for the Leader of the Government in this place, but that embarrassment does not mean that the question should be ruled out of order.
—To the extent that any of it related to Senator Vanstone's department, if she wishes to make any comment upon it, she may do so or take it on notice.

talker.name: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
Senator VANSTONE
talker.role: Minister for Justice

talk.start.para: —I indicated in relation to the first question that I did not have a brief on that. If I may combine a response to the point of order as part of the answer, I had thought that supplementaries would arise out of the answer. On that basis, there is nothing in the supplementary that could arise out of the answer because the answer was, `I do not have a brief.' But, in my usual courteous way, I will try to find out for Senator Lundy because she is one of the people over there who are usually charming, more often than not. I will get some information for her from the Attorney-General as soon as I can and I will send it to her.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for the Environment, Senator Hill. I refer the minister to a report in today's West Australian concerning the construction by the Department of Conservation and Land Management of roads into the Wattle Forest block near Walpole in preparation for the logging of the area. I ask: given that the area in question was specifically mentioned in the World Heritage report, which was completed for the state-Commonwealth regional forest agreement process, as being worthy of further consideration for inclusion in a protected reserve system, does the minister agree that this represents yet another example of the Department of Conservation and Land Management's total contempt for the RFA process as being an impediment to its real agenda of promoting the logging of old growth forests for quick profit?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: —We are in the process of negotiating a regional forest agreement for Western Australia. The objective of that process is to provide a contribution to a comprehensive, adequate and representative conservation reserve system for Australia. A very important part of that contribution will, in fact, be made from Western Australia where there are very important forests, both old growth and more recent growth. Another objective of the RFA process is to provide for sustainable forest harvesting in a way that can give certainty to the industry and provide long-term jobs for, in this instance, Western Australians.

answer.para: The honourable senator will be aware of the options paper, having been circulated, and that we are in the process of a public consultation period. Those consultations have been taking place in the forest region. We have had one meeting of officials briefing both ministers—me, on behalf of the Commonwealth, and Western Australian Minister Edwardes—on the preliminary observations arising out of those consultations. That consultation period will come to an end soon. We will commence a negotiation to achieve the objectives that I set out in the first instance.

As far as the Commonwealth is concerned, we have put in place an interim protected regime to protect the values that will be an important part of the ultimate outcome. We are proceeding towards a long-term agreement which can provide both those conservation and those employment benefits that we are seeking.

talk.start.para: —I have a supplementary question for the minister. I remind the minister that, when I asked him a question on 26 May this year about the destruction of Hilliger block by CALM, he replied then that I had the opportunity to raise my concerns during this famous public consultation process, deliberately ignoring the fact that there was little point if CALM had already destroyed the area. I ask, therefore: given that we now have further evidence of CALM's contempt for the RFA process and for the concerns of the majority of Western Australians about the logging of old growth forests, what action will the minister take to stop CALM destroying any more forests before the regional forest agreement is properly negotiated to the satisfaction of all parties, including the conservation movement, or is the minister now prepared to admit that the process is a total sham?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: —CALM is responsible, as is the Western Australian partner, for authorising the harvesting of forests. It must do so in accordance with the agreement on deferral that is reached in conjunction with the Western Australian and Commonwealth governments. As the honourable senator would know, CALM is currently the subject of a performance audit by the Western Australian EPA. The people of Western Australia can be assured, with those processes in place, including the independent performance audit, that the senator has the sort of safeguards she is seeking.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Health and Family Services. Can the minister confirm recent Health Insurance Commission figures that the Howard government has closed down at least 43 Medicare offices nationwide? Can the minister confirm that the government's only answer to more than two million clients previously served by on-the-spot service from these offices is that they should use a fax machine? Can the minister confirm that the Medicare offices closed down by this government had previously processed over 6 million claims per year for items such as Medicare and child-care assistance? Is the government seriously expecting that it can process this volume of claims by fax? Is this not just another example of this government withdrawing Commonwealth services from the people who pay for them and wasting taxpayers' money at the same time?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Bishop for the question. Senator Bishop does not inspire the frisson of excitement that we used to get when another—the former—Senator Bishop was in the chamber because this Senator Bishop reads press releases put out by the shadow minister for health and believes them.
—Nobody could be that silly.

—I acknowledge Senator Ian Macdonald's remark that nobody could be that silly. Obviously he does. It is true that some offices are closing down. However, the government is introducing a system whereby other agencies will open so that there will be many more offices throughout the country in pharmacies.
—That's not an office, it's a fax machine!

—`It's not an office,' Senator Forshaw says. It is not just a fax machine. Senator Forshaw thinks you can have fax machines plucked out of the air and not put in some sort of environment. The fact is that we are bringing in many more agencies where claims can be made right throughout the country.

answer.para: I notice that Mr Lee put out a press release stating that Medibank Private was closing down its agencies.
Senator Forshaw interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Forshaw said that something like 19 of the 22 offices of Medicare Private are closing in regional Victoria. Yet again he is incorrect. Medibank Private has established its own new national distribution arrangements. There are 91 Medibank Private business centres Australia wide. There are two-way agency arrangements with 226 Medicare offices, which will allow Medibank Private members to drop claims at any Medicare location.

answer.para: There are pharmacy agency arrangements across Australia and other agency partnerships, including over 100 cash claiming agencies in selected locations. Finally, Senator Forshaw might be interested to know that there will be access to telephone inquiry services Australia wide and fax and telephone claim lodgments in rural and regional Queensland. That is the complete opposite of what Senator Bishop is alleging, because he has followed a press release issued by the shadow Minister for Health and Family Services. I refute the implications of the question; they are false implications. It is true that in rural Victoria there is a re-allocation of some of those agencies in relation to Medibank Private. However, overall, the numbers will increase right across Australia.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Can the minister confirm that the closure of these 43 Medicare offices by the Howard government means that some 4,740 square metres of office space has been dumped by the government on a depressed commercial retail market, with some leases not due to expire until well into the next century? How many of these offices remain vacant? What is the potential total Commonwealth liability in dead rent in these offices? Can the minister confirm the commission's advice that over $300,000 has already been paid out in recent weeks as dead rent? Finally, if the minister cannot answer these questions, I ask that they be taken on notice.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I obviously do not have a brief detailing the amount.
—Why not? You were asked the same question three weeks ago at estimates.

—Because Senator Bishop has asked questions about the square footage of office space and the contracts that have been let in relation to it. I am happy to get that from the minister and provide him with an answer to it. They are not in the brief that has been supplied to me. With regard to the facts of the matter, I am happy to supply them. I will get them from the minister as soon as they can be made available to us.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Will the minister inform the Senate of progress by the government in delivering the most comprehensive small business reforms in more than two decades? What resistance has there been to measures introduced by the Howard government to assist this vital sector of the Australian economy to grow and employ more Australians?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —It is indeed a very impressive track record. We promised to reduce paperwork and red tape for small business, and we have cut it by something like 24 per cent. We have introduced award simplification, which makes an enormous difference for small businesses being held to ransom by you and your union mates. It certainly enables them to calculate what they have to pay and to enter into sensible workplace negotiations.

answer.para: We have eliminated the fringe benefits tax on vital travel costs. We have cut capital gains tax on small business rollover and on retirement. We have twice reduced the provisional uplift factor. We have established a small business registration point. Any number of changes have made a dramatic difference to the way in which small business operates. Certainly the introduction of the small business innovation investment fund and the new apprenticeship schemes are two classic examples.

What do we have by way of contrast? It is only a week or so back that the Leader of the Opposition was effectively confirming that Labor is going into the next election without any policies whatsoever. He said, `When I actually get into power, I'm going to put forward a set of policies which I believe the Australian people will rally to.' In other words, he will tell us after the election what his policies are. We only have to remember back a couple of years when small business interest rates got to 25 per cent and Mr Keating said, `So they're feeling the pinch. They ought to say that small business is not for them, because it's never going to get any better.'

Labor has never repudiated that outrageously offensive remark, but in many ways it simply typifies Labor's attitude to small business. When we reformed the unfair dismissal laws we were opposed tooth and nail. What did COSBOA say? It said that those laws, introduced by Labor and held on by them until the very end, cost something in the order of 50,000 jobs. They never learn. They simply keep bringing in here people who have no understanding of small business.

Look at the Northern Territory. They did it again. Bob Collins was one of the few non-unionists. What happened? They wheeled in yet another union hack. It is no surprise that these people have not the slightest idea what small business is about. We have reformed retail tenancy laws. We have made it much easier for small business to deal direct, and yet this mob opposite is going to repeal the secondary boycott provisions. In other words, once again they will roll over and allow their union mates to call the shots.

It is quite clear why Labor has no policies, but it does not worry us in a sense because they will be judged by their track record, and that is one that makes it very clear indeed that they have not the slightest interest in or understanding of how small business works. They will simply continue to go to the election absolutely policy bankrupt, in no shape or form ready to fight an election. We welcome that. I think Tim Colebatch got it absolutely right this morning: if you are not interested in policies, you do not deserve to be in government.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, Senator Alston. Is it true that the minister has told his department that he is concerned that his responses to correspondence are not sufficiently engaging with the recipient? Is it true that he has told his department that, `When a complaint is being made about a third party which we agree with, like the ABC, we are not sufficiently supportive in the response'? Isn't the minister effectively requiring his department to be as partisan as he is in regard to his relentless criticism of the ABC?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Let me give you an example. If I had a number of complaints about Senator Faulkner—and I get them constantly wherever I go—and people wrote to me about it—
—Table them!

—I would have to wash my hands before I picked them up. I would not be interested in tabling them. The sensible approach would not be to write back a letter saying, `Thank you very much for your letter regarding Senator Faulkner. I'll take it into account in future dealings.' The sensible way to reply is to empathise with the correspondent if the concerns expressed are consistent with government policy. I would have thought that was fairly simple.

answer.para: Maybe in government you were not interested. All you did was simply take what was given to you and fire back something. I remember that former Senator Button used to sit in here, and it went on for days and days, and all he ever did was fill out correspondence. He was not the slightest bit interested in what was being put. He was simply just putting his signature to the letters as quickly as possible.

We have a different attitude. If people take the trouble to write to us about issues that concern them, the least we can do is show that we have read the letter and that we sympathise with them where it is consistent with our overall approach. Where there are policy decisions that might be of interest to them, those matters ought to be brought to their attention. I am appalled that the Senator Faulkners of this world think that somehow we should ignore people's concerns, that we should simply play a straight bat, and that we should not make them aware of what our policy concerns are. That is not our attitude.

All I can say is that I would be permanently disabled if I had to reply in writing to all the oral complaints I have had about Senator Faulkner's performance on television. It is absolutely appalling. To think that if someone wrote to me complaining about that I should not write back and tell them what I really thought of him is an absolute laugh.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is it true that the minister's office has recently returned a number of ministerial representations to the department so that they can, in fact, be made much more critical of the ABC?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —As I have said, it is our approach—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senator Faulkner has asked a question and he is entitled to hear the reply.
—Do you want to hear it or not?
—We'd like to hear the truth.

—Let me tell it to you. Let me give it to you unvarnished. If someone writes to me, they want to know what I think, don't they? They do. I assume they do. I might be a bit naive, but I assume that if they write to me and say `Dear Senator Alston, here are my concerns', that they expect me to write back and address their concerns. All right? So what I do is that I ensure that when I write back to them I am actually relevant to what they are saying. I do not just do what Senator Ray would have done: blindly take a pile of letters, doesn't matter what the complaint was, he wouldn't bother reading it but just put his initials on the bottom and away it goes. That is not the way to respond to constituents' and community concerns. That is the way you lose touch. That is the way you rule your union mates—(Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Special Minister of State, Senator Minchin. I refer to the Wik deal between the Prime Minister and Senator Harradine. Minister, are you aware that indigenous people are being put through the wringer on this matter? Can you inform the Senate whether the National Indigenous Working Group has been consulted by your government in this latest round of talks, or do you think they are irrelevant to the debate? Minister, what happened to this morning's announcement? Didn't your backbenchers like it when the Prime Minister briefed them? Minister, what are the sticking points between the Prime Minister and Senator Harradine? When are the indigenous people going to find out what has happened to their native title rights?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I inform the Senate that of course there is no deal, there is no agreement. Senator Harradine and the government are working in the national interest to see if we can resolve the differences between the House of Representatives and the Senate on this vital piece of legislation to overcome the obstruction presented to us by the Labor Party and the Democrats and Greens who clearly have no interest in resolving this issue, and who seem hell bent on forcing the government to a double dissolution on this issue by their insistence that the government include in the bill amendments which they never agreed to when they had the opportunity to deal with this act in government.

answer.para: Senator Bolkus interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order, Senator Bolkus!

—We are working as hard as we can with Senator Harradine to see if it is possible to resolve the areas of disagreement and to produce an outcome that will be in the national interest to amend Paul Keating's Native Title Act in a way that will serve all Australians and provide a fair balance on the outstanding issues.

answer.para: The question of indigenous consultation is of course an important one, and I respect Senator Woodley for raising it. But I would say that the Prime Minister went out of his way from the minute the Wik judgment was handed down to consult as closely as he possibly could with the leaders of the indigenous communities of Australia. We had something like 100 separate meetings with the indigenous leaders of Australia. The Prime Minister had Gatjil Djerrkura and other indigenous leaders to the lodge on several occasions, separately and with other leaders of industry groups around Australia. Those discussions continued right through to about April or May of last year, when the National Indigenous Working Group, of its own volition, left the table. The Indigenous Working Group walked away from the consultation process which we had put in train because they said they were no longer interested in talking to us.

We did in fact take account of many of the indigenous concerns in presenting the Native Title Amendment Bill to this parliament. You on the other side know what those areas are in relation to agreements and representative bodies et cetera. The bill does protect and preserve native title. We have respected native title on pastoral leases, and I would have thought that you would have at least been prepared to acknowledge, given the outrageous and ridiculous position taken by the One Nation Party on this issue, that the government's position does indeed represent a fair balance of all the competing interests on this very sensitive and difficult issue for the government and for the people of Australia.

I remind you, Senator Woodley, that the National Indigenous Working Group's position was outlined in this so-called yellow book. This was the position which the Indigenous Working Group said was their bottom line, and that anything not in this book was not of interest to them and they were just going to walk away from it. One part of the bottom line for them is:
No extinguishment of native title by the Commonwealth, States or Territories without the informed consent of native title holders.

That is a polite way of saying that there is an absolute Aboriginal veto on any development of 79 per cent of Australia. It is a completely unacceptable position, which not even the Labor Party was prepared to put forward. But that was put forward as a bottom line—a veto on any development on land that may be native title land in Australia, which, as a result of the Wik decision, amounts to 79 per cent of Australia. So their position was unacceptable not only to the government but to the Labor Party itself, both in government and in opposition.

We have sought to consult as closely as we can with indigenous groups in developing the amendment bill. The process we are going through now is to see if agreement can be reached with Senator Harradine to get this bill through the parliament and resolve this issue once and for all.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you for that answer, Minister. I refer to that part of the question in which you spoke about the national interest. Is it not in the national interest that you speak to indigenous people in this round of consultations—speak to them, not at them?
—This is a sermon, John!
—Order, Senator Abetz! Senators on my right will cease interjecting.

—This is an important question. Is it not the case, Minister, that you have had meetings with representatives of the mining, farming and pastoral industries in this latest round of talks? Is the Prime Minister going to use indigenous people as human shields against David Oldfield's One Nation in the lead-up to the next election?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Special Minister of State;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —It is about time the Democrats and Greens in particular, but also the Labor Party, took account of the disastrous effect of the current Native Title Act on rural and regional Australia, and of the disastrous impact their amendments would have. They have completely ignored rural and regional Australia, and they are partly responsible for the rise of One Nation in this country because of their obstruction and intransigence on the native title issue. We could resolve this issue if they would cooperate with us in getting a fair solution to this native title issue.
—Senator Brown, are you raising a point of order?
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. Whether representing One Nation's point of view or not, the minister should not shout across the chamber.
—You are debating this issue, Senator. You can take the matter up afterwards.

—My question is directed to Senator Alston, the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. I refer the minister to the resignation in April of this year of the chairman of the Australian Rail Track Corporation, Mr Ken Baxter. Can the minister confirm that Mr Baxter was forced to resign after the revelation of a conflict of interest in the form of his role on the ARC and a position in a company called Red River? Can the minister also confirm that the department referred this matter to the Australian Securities Commission following advice from the Australian Government Solicitor? What action has the government taken to ascertain whether Mr Baxter's conflict may have contaminated any decisions or advice he gave to the government?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I can confirm that—
—Did you ask Jeff Kennett?
—Senator Carr, a question has been asked by Senator Quirke, and Senator Alston is entitled to answer it without you interfering.

—I doubt there is anyone in Victoria who would speak to Senator Carr, let alone Mr Kennett. I can confirm that Mr Ken Baxter resigned as chairman of the Australian Rail Track Corporation on Friday 29 May this year. The advice from the secretary to the department is that a claim had been made of a possible conflict of interest involving Mr Baxter in his role as chairman, and advice was sought from the Australian Government Solicitor and the Australian Securities Commission. The chairman, Mr Baxter, was then given the opportunity to respond to the claims that had been made, and in view of what was regarded as an unsatisfactory response, the department sought Mr Baxter's resignation from the position. He tendered that resignation to the company secretary on the day indicated.

answer.para: I do not know that there is much more that I can add, other than to say that the depart ment did act swiftly and promptly to address the situation and to ensure that the ARTC is able to deliver the benefits to the Australian rail industry that it desperately needs after 13 years of Labor mismanagement. If there is any other aspect of the matter, I will refer it to the minister.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that Mr Baxter has performed other work for government such as the Public Service Bill and the restructuring of DAS, has a check been undertaken as to whether any other conflicts of interest occurred?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts

talk.start.para: —I am unable to answer that, but I will direct the question to the minister's attention.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment. Minister, since coming to office this government has taken numerous steps to improve Australia's environment. This includes such matters as the establishment of Australia's largest ever environmental package, the Natural Heritage Trust; regional forest agreements to protect high conservation value forests and increase job security; implementing national environmental standards on pollution; international and industry agreements to reduce greenhouse gas emissions; enhancement and protection of world heritage properties; and the establishment of strict environmental safeguards to ensure development is sustainable. Minister, how do the government's achievements compare with those of the previous Labor government? Is the minister aware of any new policy proposals?

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: —After just over two years of government it is becoming possible to contrast the approach of the Howard government with that of the previous failed Labor government. Of course, one will remember that the approach of Labor to environmental issues was to build division and confrontation and to seek to win political points out of it, not necessarily for any environmental gain at all, whereas we have approached it quite differently, building support cooperatively with the states, the Commonwealth and stakeholders, thus achieving good environmental outcomes.

answer.para: Take forests, for example. No-one will forget Labor's approach to forests—the confrontation, the blockades and the unpleasantness with no worthwhile environmental goals at all. Remember what the Australian said about it on 3 April 1995:
Faulkner has been a disappointment as environment minister.
The Sydney Morning Herald on 23 December 1994 said:
What Keating was saying about the Minister for the Environment was that he had proved politically incompetent.
The Bulletin on 14 February 1995 said:
Faulkner has made a mess of things. The extent of his mishandling of the issue is only now becoming apparent.

Madam President, compare that with the Howard government—three regional forest agreements in place, good conservation outcomes, more than half a million hectares of new conservation reserves and, on the other hand, the possibility of another 1,250 jobs.
Moving on to greenhouse, who remembers Berlin and the delegation led by Senator Faulkner? Do you remember what the Australian said about that embarrassment on 1 April 1995:
Australia's international reputation took a battering. Its performance at Rio has left it looking inept abroad and out of step at home.

Madam President, this is Senator Faulkner's contribution. Compare it with that of the coalition government, which achieved an outcome at Rio which was good for the environment and, Senator Brown, good for jobs as well.

What about world heritage? Who remembers 13 years of Labor unable to solve the problems at Willandra with landowners who were not paid compensation? So frustrated were they with Senator Faulkner as environment minister that they had to blockade his aeroplane. Last weekend we went to Willandra and the problems of the landowners are solved—finally finished. They are now being paid fair and proper compensation. After 13 years of failed Labor on that environmental issue, the coalition comes in and fixes the problem. What about national environmental standards—

talk.start.para: —How come you are travelling at 34 per cent if you are so good!
—Order! Senator Faulkner!

—I know it is embarrassing, Madam President. The Labor Party promised national environmental protection standards for air, water and hazardous waste. It established a national council in 1994. We came to government in 1996 and it had not even had a face-to-face meeting. Senator Faulkner had not even called a face-to-face meeting.

answer.para: Under the coalition government meetings are taking place, and we now have a national measure in place for a national pollutant inventory, a second one for ambient air qualities across the whole of the nation and a third for the transport of hazardous waste. What a contrast. The coalition government is getting the job done without confrontation, with good environmental outcomes and good job outcomes. The previous Labor government could not achieve a worthwhile environmental outcome even with confrontation.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .
—I seek leave to make a brief statement. I claim to have been misrepresented by the minister in question time today.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I will not debate the point but, briefly, Minister Newman implied that I had given two different dates for the receipt of common youth allowance applications. For the record, 7 July is the date by which forms reportedly should be received—that is what I was quoting; 8 July is the date from which recipients will be breached.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator HILL
talker.role: Environment

talk.start.para: —I want to add to an answer I gave to Senator Margetts in relation to the Wattle Forest block in Western Australia. I am advised that most of Wattle Forest block is already reserved as part of the Mount Frankland National Park and only the north-western section is subject to logging. The area in question is not in a deferred forest area. As such, activity in this area will not foreclose options on the CAR system. I understand that the WA Department of Conservation and Land Management said that any proposed logging would not foreclose options for widening the existing linkage between Shannon and Mount Frankland national parks.

—The Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, by letter dated 25 June 1998, has raised with me a matter of privilege under standing order 81; namely, the unauthorised disclosure of the report of the committee of its third evaluation of the National Crime Authority on 6 April 1998.

speech.para: I am advised that the committee has followed the procedures laid down by the Senate in the resolution of 20 June 1996. This resolution requires that, in cases of unauthorised disclosure of committee documents, the committee concerned shall seek to discover the cause of the disclosure and come to a conclusion that the unauthorised disclosure has caused substantial interference with the work of the committee, before raising a matter of privilege under standing order 81. The committee having followed that process, the matter meets the criteria which I am required to consider.

I therefore determine that a motion to refer the matter to the Privileges Committee may have precedence. I table the committee's letter. A notice of motion may now be given on behalf of the committee.

talk.start.para: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

speech.para: That the following matter be referred to the Committee of Privileges:

Whether there was an unauthorised disclosure of the report of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority on the committee's third evaluation of the National Crime Authority and, if so, whether any contempt was committed by that disclosure.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston), to a question without notice asked by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) today, relating to the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.

Only yesterday in the debate on the appropriation bills, I gave lengthy examples of where this government, led by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and his Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston), have consistently attacked the ABC not only by reducing its funding by $55 million a year but also by consistent public comment claiming that the ABC is biased, the ABC is unprofessional, the ABC is against the coalition, the ABC does not report broadly enough programs and issues that are of interest to the Prime Minister or to the minister.

Today, in the question asked by Senator Faulkner we had a further example of just how far this minister will go to put the boots into the ABC, when Senator Faulkner was able to point out that a memo had been circulated in the minister's own department concerning letters that were to be sent to people who had written in to the minister on certain matters. If they were favourable to the minister there would be a more effusive and warm response for the minister to sign, and in particular when they get letters written in from people attacking the ABC because that is in line with government policy. That was the example given by the minister.

I find it extraordinary that the example he would give is about the ABC, a statutory authority for which he is responsible and for which he should have some responsibility to publicly defend and explain its charter. But no, not this minister, he is always in there taking every opportunity to put the boot into the ABC. This is an unparalleled and unprecedented performance by any minister who has been in charge of the ABC since it was formed and created by an act of the Australian parliament over 60 years ago.

Of course, we know the minister is aided and abetted in this by the Prime Minister's own obsessions about the ABC, the Prime Minister's own chip on the shoulder and the Prime Minister's own vendetta to get even with every story and every comment run by the ABC that the Prime Minister thinks is against him or the Liberal Party of Australia. So the Prime Minister has egged on this minister to have this attitude towards the ABC.

I notice that Senator Alston did not put in the memo or instruct his department that maybe they should have the same response, for example, towards Telstra. I would imagine the minister gets many more letters complaining about Telstra's charges and about Telstra's service. Only yesterday we had the example given by the ACA in its quarterly report to March of this year that new telephone connection services in country areas have dropped by 17 per cent in the first full year of the one-third privatisation of Telstra. But no, that would not worry him. The minister does not want to get into criticising Telstra or even showing some sympathy for some of the legitimate complaints against Telstra, because he wants to promote Telstra for its privatisation. The one example he gives of the ABC, again, absolutely fits the pattern of abuse from this minister.

We say to the Australian people that it is not just the $55 million cut per annum that the ABC has suffered—most savagely—by this government since it came to office in breaking every promise it made during the 1996 election campaign to maintain the funding. Even on election night after they had won the election, Senator Alston reiterated the coalition's commitment to maintain the funding for the ABC. The ABC is not only at risk from the cuts to its funding but also these attacks come about because this government, the Prime Minister and the minister for communications are all about one thing only, and that is destroying the ABC as a broad based national and comprehensive news broadcaster in Australia.

The Prime Minister and the minister for communications want to intimidate the ABC, particularly in the lead-up to the coming election. They know that, in many areas of Australia, the ABC is the only independent voice for Australians to get factual information about current events, about politics, and about social and economic issues in Australia. Sometimes those comments are not favourable to this government's policies; sometimes they are not favourable to the Labor Party; and sometimes they are not favourable to other political parties. But the ABC has a long history of providing a balance. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I notice that there is no-one from the government side—
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. There were two other senators standing. Senator Carr was not even standing.
—I was standing.
—Senator Patterson, I have called Senator Carr. I will call others standing as well.

—I notice that the government has not responded to this motion to take note of the answer from Senator Alston because it has nothing to respond to. As far as the government is concerned, it is appropriate, fair and reasonable for this minister to instruct his department to join with him in its crusade against the ABC. What we have before us today is a proposition where the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) who is the minister responsible for the ABC—a person who ought to be defending the ABC and its legitimate function within our society—undertaking a role on behalf of the Liberal Party to attack the ABC, to vilify the ABC and to seek to denigrate the ABC in the minds of the Australian public.

speech.para: What we have is instructions being issued by this minister to public servants—not just on behalf of himself but on behalf of his ministerial advisers and his chief of staff—that, in response to criticisms raised with the minister, the department should join with the minister in attacking the ABC. What the minister has instructed his department to do is to become more engaged with criticism for the ABC and to say that, when a complaint is being made about a third party with which it agrees, like the ABC, the department is currently not sufficiently supportive in its response.

The real question here is: why does this government and this minister hate the ABC with such a passion? Why do they hate the ABC with such a passion? They do not like the ABC because it represents a threat to their notion of what is fair and reasonable. That is not to say that this coalition government does not have a view about balanced coverage in terms of public affairs. The difference is that they have a different view of what is balanced. They believe there are two sides to every question—there is a National Party side to the question and then there is a Liberal Party side to the question. There should be no other consideration of any other views in our society. We should not have an independent broadcaster capable of representing the broad range of values in our society. We should have a broadcaster that represents government views. That is their notion of what the ABC is all about.

What we have seen throughout the life of this government is a consistent and persistent campaign of denigration against the ABC. What we have heard is senior ministers from the government denigrating the ABC—from the Treasurer (Mr Costello), who described the ABC as lacking accountability, to the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), who said that the ABC was, in his view, politically correct to a fault, to this minister, who says that the ABC budget was bloated. These are the sorts of attitudes we see expressed by these politicians in this coalition about what should be an institution defended by both sides in this parliament. What we have seen is a deliberate and systematic campaign by this government to undermine the integrity and the authority of the ABC. They have done so by reducing the resource provided to that body by this parliament and then back up that reduction in resource by a consistent campaign of abuse.

As a consequence, $55 million per year has been withdrawn from the ABC. The budget for the ABC has been reduced from about $555 million to just under $500 million per year. As a direct consequence of this government's action, a whole range of programs and a whole range of services to regional Australia and to different communities within Australia have been removed by this government's actions. That is a direct consequence of taking away well in excess of 10 per cent per year of the budget provided to the ABC.

In the arts area, we have had a whole series of programs removed, as we have in comedy, in drama, in sport and in documentaries. We have seen the services reduced in terms of the network services available. We have seen international services withdrawn. What do we get from this government? We get the consistent push that the bureaucracy now has to join in the holy jihad against the ABC and that the department has to join with the minister in its assault upon the independence and integrity of the ABC and seek to denigrate and abuse the ABC for doing nothing other than its job in terms of its charter and in terms of its capacity to represent the different views in our society. This government ought to be condemned and this minister ought to be condemned, because it is quite clear that he has been exposed here today. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —That was an amazing performance by Senator Carr. People ought to be reminded that in the last year when the Labor Party was in government they exceeded their income. They spent $10.5 billion a year more than the money received from taxpayers. Anybody who runs a household budget knows that you cannot keep doing that. You cannot keep spending more money than you get in.
—It was actually $12 billion a year every year for 10 years.

—Yes. Senator Campbell reminds me that it was $12 billion a year more every year for 10 years. I would have got on to that. Every year they kept spending more. What they were doing was frittering away the inheritance we have been left by previous generations and borrowing from the next generation. Senator Carr tells us that we have taken money out of the ABC, but, Senator Carr, I want to know where the Labor Party is going to get the money to put back into the ABC. Are they going to borrow it from overseas, borrow it from foreign countries, borrow it from the next generation, borrow it from his kids, borrow it from Senator Ian Campbells's kids or borrow it from the kids of the future to pay for it today?
—Why do you hate the ABC? Answer the question! Why do you hate the ABC?

—What we have to do is cut our cloth to fit. We have to be able to live within our means and we are not living within our means. When Senator Carr says we hate the ABC, one thing I did find of great concern to me when I was watching the last election campaign was that I saw one of the senior reporters talking about the seats and the results as they came in. A Labor seat fell—lots of Labor seats fell at the last election—and the ABC reporter said, `Oh, we have just lost another seat.'
—We?

—Yes. They said, `We have just lost another seat,' meaning Labor. That was an unbiased ABC reporter. It transpires that that unbiased ABC reporter is now a candidate for a state seat in Victoria. They pushed through the factional fights in Victoria. A candidate who had a claim on that seat has been pushed aside. So we have a Labor candidate in the seat of Northcote in Victoria who is an ex-ABC reporter who sat on that unbiased ABC report of the election and said, `We have just lost a seat.' That is not the sort of thing we want to hear.

speech.para: The other day I was talking to a friend of mine. She said that she had been incensed by something she had watched on the ABC and said it was so biased. This person is a swing ing voter. She said, `I am so upset about the fact that the ABC is biased.' I said, `Why don't you write to them? They have a thing called a code of practice. You can get a brochure and they will tell you how you can complain to the ABC. If you don't get a reply, then there's a process that goes on if you do not get a reply in so many days.' We rang up the ABC and guess what? There were no code of practice brochures available. I asked for them in the estimates committee and they said they would get them to me. I am still waiting.

Do you know how I can get those forms? I can get them off the Internet. This person does not have access to the Internet. So I had to print one out and send it to her. So that is how easy it is to complain about bias in the ABC. You cannot get a code of practice from them. This should be our ABC that allows us to tell them whether we think they are biased. I am putting the ABC on notice: get those forms out so that when people ask us about how they can complain about bias in the ABC they can at least go through the right process.

Also we heard in estimates that the committee to which you can complain about bias is absolutely stacked with journalists, not with people in the community. With all due respect to journalists, they are like politicians, although politicians better represent the community—they all have a particular view. I think the committee should be formed by people who can make an unbias, objective decision about whether there has been bias in the ABC. Maybe they could have one or two journalists, but to have a whole committee of journalists is not what we call cricket. So the ABC has a way to go.

To say that we hate the ABC is wrong. What we want is an ABC which is unbiased, which presents the facts, which is a genuine broadcaster of apolitical information, not taking one view or the other. They should also make themselves available. I put on the record here that I have just written to Donald McDonald recently to thank him for the ABC's involvement and commitment to the International Year of Older Persons. I had cause to write to him and thank him for the plans they are already making for the Interna tional Year of Older Persons. As chairman of the committee responsible for the International Year of Older Persons, I am delighted that the ABC is going to be involved in that. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Let me make a couple of comments about what Senator Patterson said. First of all, the body within the Senate which deals with complaints is the Privileges Committee. Let me tell you that the Privileges Committee is stacked with politicians. Does that mean that they cannot be fair and reasonable? Does that mean that they cannot actually be reasonable? Of course it does not. What a ridiculous thing to say.

speech.para: What about the ALP person who happens to be a journalist? Are you telling me that Mr Henshaw, who is now the Liberal Party candidate in the seat of Dickson and an ex-ABC talkback host in Queensland, was biased in favour of the Liberal Party when he was with the ABC? That is a pretty outrageous thing to say. I do not believe that he was biased, and I do not believe that that other person was biased either. People belong to political parties. It is the way it happens. People stand for election for political parties. You did. I did, and I am going to do it again. That is the way it happens. This is a democracy. In this country we are allowed to belong to political parties, and we are allowed to have jobs while we do that. We are allowed to stand for election.

Let me turn to a few things the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) said. First of all, the minister said that it is only polite to answer letters. I may have this almost right—I am sure I have the gist of it right. If someone writes to me, then they expect me to write back and address their concerns. That is perfectly reasonable and correct. So they do. If you do not address their concerns, if you do not answer their letters, then that is the way you lose touch. That is all true.

Let me ask the minister—unfortunately he is not here, but I am sure he is listening—what about the 17,000 people who wrote to him complaining about cuts to the ABC? They have not received a reply. The minister has not replied to them, and the department has not replied. Even though the department has been instructed to tell them how awful the ABC is, they have not replied. There was no reply at all. I think the minister could lose touch if he does not reply to those 17,000 people, and I think he should do it fairly soon.

What about Mr Mansfield's inquiry which received 10,615 submissions—the vast majority of which were saying, `Do not destroy the ABC. Do not cut the ABC. Do not kill the funding of the ABC'?
