subdebateinfo.title: Report of Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee

talk.start.para: —I present the report of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee on the provisions of the Wheat Marketing Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 , together with submissions and Hansard record of proceedings and move:

speech.para: That the report be printed.

talk.start.para: —I wish to speak only briefly to indicate that the Wheat Marketing Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 was referred to the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee pursuant to the Selection of Bills Committee report, and the committee was originally to report by 5 p.m. today. In fact, the matter was postponed because the committee was not in a position to report. This was a very rushed process. This bill was referred by the Selection of Bills Committee last Wednesday, with the closing of submissions on Friday. There was a hearing on Monday which concluded at 7.30 p.m., the Hansard of which was not available until 4 p.m.
—Today?

—Today, yes. The committee's draft report was not with the opposition until 5.15 p.m. The evidence from the Taxation Office, which was relevant to the consideration of the committee, was not received by my office until approximately 6 p.m. The committee met at 6.45 p.m. and, unfortunately, no member of the opposition was available to attend that meeting, given that the notice regarding the meeting was communicated to us late in the day.

speech.para: We have prepared and submitted a minority report in a very short space of time. We had requested that this particular report be deferred until tomorrow on the basis that we did not believe we had adequate time to prepare a proper report. Given that the report is being presented at 10.15 and, as I understand it, could easily have been deferred until sometime tomorrow morning, I think it is rather unfortunate that the government did not have the grace to allow for the extension of the period for the committee to report on this bill given that the timetable of the report—that is, presenting the report now rather than tomorrow—will have no bearing on the actual timetable for the debate of this bill.

The only issue that might have arisen prior to the presentation of the report were it deferred until some hour tomorrow morning was that perhaps we would have been debating whether the bill will be exempted from the cut-off. If we are debating that tomorrow morning, it may still be that this bill is not exempted from the cut-off in which case it will not be debated in this session and will be debated in the next session in which the Senate sits. That is a matter which none of us has any certainty about at the moment, but we hear certain things in the media which indicate that perhaps we are likely to be here in August.

Nevertheless, we are talking about a bill which affects an export industry which returns billions of dollars to the Australian economy and affects thousands of rural producers and thousands of wheat growers. For this bill to be dealt with in this way, particularly in relation to the reporting of the committee and for the committee to have been given such an inadequate timetable, means that—I make no apologies for this—the opposition's minority report is not what I would have wished it to be in normal circumstances.

But the reality was that we had an extremely short timetable in which to prepare a minority report. There are still issues which warrant, in my view, serious consideration. There are issues which industry representatives have indicated they would want satisfaction for before they were satisfied the bill should pass in those circumstances. I think it is important that I draw that matter to the Senate's attention in terms of the tabling of this report and the resolution that the bill be printed.

talk.start.para: —I want to make one brief comment in terms of the processes as the chair of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee. The recommendation for the reference was from the opposition. The program was put to the Selection of Bills Committee by the whip of the opposition. The program under which we dealt with the report was a recommendation that came to the parliament from the Selection of Bills Committee. It was your own program that was put down by the opposition in terms of dealing with this bill and that timetable. The rest of the legislation in terms of what is before us and this report will be debated at the proper time when the legislation comes before us.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I thank the Senate for its indulgence. I rise to support the remarks of Senator O'Brien, as he has quite clearly outlined the difficulties under which the opposition has been placed in this matter. I also concede there have been difficulties under which all members of the committee have been placed with respect to this matter, not the least of whom would be Senator Crane, the chair. The reason for that is the government's incompetence in dealing with this legislation.

speech.para: This is a most serious matter. This legislation has its genesis in the proposals to restructure the Australian Wheat Board. The first set of legislation came before the parliament last year. Senators will remember that it was the opposition's recommendation at that time that, because of the serious issues that were still unresolved within the industry—I repeat: within the industry—the original legislation, the Wheat Marketing Legislation Amendment Bill 1997, be withdrawn and that the whole package of legislation be brought back before this parliament this year.

We were told that it was likely that the legislation, which is now the subject of consideration of the committee's report, would be available probably in May of this year. That was our recommendation, but our recommendation was not picked up. What ultimately happened was that the parliament debated and dealt with the first tranche of the legislation involving the restructuring of the Australian Wheat Board. But, as I said, there were very serious outstanding issues still to be resolved—issues which went to the structure of the new companies and the share allocation of the company to replace the Australian Wheat Board; issues relating to the appropriate way in which the wheat industry fund should be dealt with; and particularly important issues regarding the taxation treatment of grower funds within the wheat industry fund.

Those issues were on the table and were still not resolved at the time the legislation was dealt with by this parliament last year. We were assured at the time that those issues would be resolved before the second set of legislation came before the parliament. Here it is now, 30 June, the end of the financial year and we have a situation where the committee has met and taken evidence from grower organisations around this country and it is still abundantly clear that there is no agreement across the broad range of organisations within the wheat industry. Even those organisations that support this legislation have raised serious reservations.

In conclusion, Senator Crane's analysis of how this matter has come before the committee is incorrect. We have cooperated all the way with the government. It is on their hands that the legislation has not been dealt with.

debate.para: Motion (by Senator Parer) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —One Nation has of recent times been the subject of numerous speeches and commentaries, and tonight I wish to add my few thoughts. The degree of support One Nation ostensibly enjoys and the reasons for it are the subject matter of my contribution this evening. At the outset let me place on record my concern at and repulsion of One Nation's policies. In so doing, I do not seek to con demn those who have voted in Queensland or indicated support through opinion polls.

speech.para: The policy elitism of recent years has been the factor in some members of our community expressing discontent with the established parties, which especially includes the Greens WA and the Democrats, who under the previous government were able to have too great a say about the issues of the day thereby often denying the aspirations of the vast bulk of Australians, some of whom are now rebelling. This political and policy elitism was, and still is, very destructive of our social fabric. The former Democrat leader admits to as much in an article in the Australian of Thursday, 18 June 1998. The Democrats are typical of that elitism, playing up to obscure policy positions and demanding their adoption in exchange for support at the expense of mainstream aspirations.

The Greens WA are also typical of that elitism. The Tasmanian Green senator yesterday asked a question oozing with smarmy elitism—exactly the behaviour and attitude which so many are now rebelling against. Allow me to remind the Senate what the question was. It stated:

My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs. You will have noticed One Nation's new policy of banning immigrants who do not pass an English test. Would it not be simpler to block or export people who are not clear on the name of our country and who think it is an eight letter word, minus the`l', pronounced `Austraya'?

That kind of question is hurtful and divisive to many thousands within our Australian community. If you do not spend all your time in the wilderness and, in fact, you do bother to mix with real people, as I and my colleagues on this side do, you readily understand that many thousands of our fellow Australians use that pronunciation for their country in the pubs, clubs, the RSLs, at churches, at parents and friends groups, at the football—you name it. There are thousands of Australians who pronounce `Australia' in the fashion of the leader of One Nation.

How she pronounces words is completely and utterly irrelevant to the debate. The Green WA attempt at personal humiliation because of a perceived lack of elocution should not disqualify any of us from partaking in the future of this country. That sort of question was typical of the divisiveness which I condemn One Nation for.

On the basis of the Greens senator's concern about elocution, I suppose people like Dr Hewson and Robert Tickner, as two examples, should have been disqualified from participating in the national debate. The Greens senator may want us all to speak the Queen's English—a laudable aim but hardly vital. And the personal and immature attack of the Greens senator will undoubtedly drive more support to One Nation. Rather than concentrating on elocution, I suggest that we as a nation ought to be concentrating on content.

The task for this country is not to engage in schoolyard bullyboy behaviour—trying to tease somebody about the way they speak—but rather to engage in the clash of ideas and vision for this nation. The strident commentaries of the Left and their fellow travellers have led to counter overreaction by elements of the community to the contrived overreaction by the Left to the policy positions of the day.

Just take the 10-point plan, for example. The 10-point plan now looks so distinctly moderate next to One Nation's one-point plan, which is to totally abolish native title, a horrid prospect for this country. Yet our approach—which was moderate, which was considered, which was mature, which did take into account the possible reactions by different sides of the community—was pilloried by elements of the media who sought to portray it as extreme and racist, which it clearly is not. Those who need to live with native title and who do live with native title knew those allegations to be false. Unfortunately, what happens is that when moderate solutions are not successful otherwise moderate sensible people are seduced and/or driven by more extreme elements into the arms of more extreme solutions.

A case in point is the avoiding of environmental issues by the major parties. As a result, the Green movement started. Similarly, if the mainstream view is not reflective of the aspirations of the people, you will then get other extreme organisations forming such as One Nation.

talk.start.para: —And the Liberals.

—Senator Bartlett makes that marvellous interjection that the Liberal Party is somehow an extremist party—that from the person who claims to be the national campaign coordinator of the Australian Democrats reflects very poorly—
—A substantial claim.
—on the Australian Democrats and, of course, indicates why their standing in the polls is receiving a substantial decline.
—Look at One Nation in Tasmania, Senator Abetz.

—Madam President, isn't it amazing how the Australian Democrats go to you and ask you for protection against interjections during question time and other occasions and then have the audacity to engage in exactly the same behaviour which they so piously object to in the media? And for the record, Senator Natasha Stott Despoja was the interjector and the worst offender.

speech.para: I will not allow myself to be distracted too much. In relation to the issue of the English language being spoken by our migrants, can I suggest that the One Nation policy is both hurtful and extreme. It would have meant that people such as Sir Arvi Parbo, Victor Chang and others may not have been able to come into this country and make the substantial contribution that they have made. And there would be very many Australians who feel very uncomfortable with One Nation's comments in relation to the speaking of the English language, because a lot of people within the community at large who are making a contribution today would have come to this country in the position of being hardly able to speak one word or a few words of English. So for One Nation to make those comments I find to be hurtful, distasteful and very divisive.

I can understand their concern if their view is that migrants ought to be taught English and assisted with the language, because that is so vital if you are to participate within society. So what they ought to be arguing for, rather than their extremist policy, is the encouragement of migrants and the Australian migrant English program which the minister for immigration runs.

There are other matters that I wanted to canvass. Time has run out, but what we as a nation need to do is not engage in the sort of petty politicking of the Greens senator during question time yesterday. What we have to deal with is the real issues, the real content, and debunk the policies of One Nation once and for all to ensure that they do not get any stronger foothold in this country.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to speak on a matter that is very important to a whole host of small businesses around this country involved in a whole range of activities, including the music industry. Primarily, I want to speak about government proposals in copyright amendment legislation to change the laws of this country that apply to copyright and, in particular, those that relate to the music industry.

speech.para: But there are two very important points to be made about how the government has gone about this. They brought in two bills: Copyright Amendment Bill 1997 and Copyright Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1997 . The first bill proposes to amend laws that relate to labelling and packaging. If those bills are passed by this chamber, they will have an immense effect on many small businesses around the country that have developed their business on the basis of a particular brand, label of a product or name of a product.

As a member of parliament, I have received numerous letters from many of these businesses, saying that they were basically unaware of the government's intention to introduce such legislation. For many of them—some of them have developed their businesses over a long period—it would mean a significant decline in their business, or it could wipe them out altogether.

As I say, I have received letters from the small business community. It is also interesting to note that a letter has been circulated to some members of parliament from the Sydney Olympic Games Organising Committee that goes to this very question of sponsorship and the impact that this legislation which has been proposed by the government could have on potential sponsors, particularly name brand sponsors like Nike, Adidas and others, who might be providing sponsorship through local businesses—the agents, agencies or distributors of those products in this country.

I could not let it pass without saying something about fishing, for which I have a great love. I refer to people who have developed a business by distributing certain imported fishing products. Whilst we are developing a very capable and a very good domestic industry in the manufacture of fishing products, we still need to import them to a large degree. There is a national distributor for, say, Shimano fishing reels, which are considered to be among the top brand of fishing reels in various aspects of fishing—although, I have to say, not in my particular pursuit. They produce very good equipment and they are distributed through a national distributor and then there are sub-distributors in each state. Those people can, in effect, be wiped out by this government's legislative proposals. I have heard that the government intends to amend Copyright Amendment Bill (No. 1). To what extent, I do not know.

talk.start.para: —Senator, the bill is on the Notice Paper . You should not be talking about the bill itself. You can canvass the issue, but not the bill.

—I do apologise, Madam President. I refer to the government's policy proposal for this type of activity—that is, the current copyright laws in this country—and how it will affect businesses in this country. Having built up a business, they then have expenditure that relates to advertising, transport and all sorts of other things that go to generating employment within our community. I think the government has fundamentally underestimated just how important are the proposals that they intend to put and the effect that they will have.

speech.para: This is no more so than in the music industry. In the music industry, it would seem that the minister's view is to pursue a commitment given by the present government prior to the last election because they felt that it was a good thing to do politically; that it would deliver them some kudos politically to provide cheaper CDs to the Australian public. Everybody is in favour of cheaper everything; we all know that. But the reality is that, when it came down to it, the Senate committee which held an inquiry into this proposal found that all of the claims of the government, including those of the ACCC, were found wanting, on the basis of substantive evidence that these claims about cheaper CDs could not be supported.

The minister made a few modifications to what he proposed. He said to the Australian public and to the music industry, `To protect you against the importation of pirated CDs, to protect you against all sorts of other manner of things illegal, we will reverse the onus of proof. That's what we'll do.' He said publicly, on any number of occasions, in radio interviews, et cetera, that that is what he would do. Unfortunately for the minister, the Attorney-General's Department said something quite different. They told the Senate committee that they could not and would not reverse the onus of proof.

I recall asking the minister a question in this place as to what was meant by the reversal of onus of proof. He said that he did not really know, that he did not really have an opinion about that. It was rather odd that he had a number of opinions about it and how it could be achieved when he made those comments publicly. The reversal of onus of proof clearly means that you require a person—in this case, say, an importer—to prove that the product they intend to import does not breach the laws of this country. That is squarely what it means.

In reality, even with what the government proposes to do, there is a very major legal problem for the music industry and the people in it. Even today, under the existing copyright laws, there is a major problem for the existing music industry to prove that the CDs that are imported into this country are illegal. It is only under the present copyright laws that there exists the possibility for them to even catch up with imported products. The copyright laws are restrictive, but they are restric tive for a very good, sound reason. The minister originally promoted the fact that the copyright laws had been changed in this country and in that country. In some countries, they have changed them back. Indeed, in one country, after 10 years of having the free market approach, they changed the law back because it had in effect wiped out their music industry.

So that is what we need to avoid as a country. I suppose the fact is that, as you pointed out, I should not talk about the bills and it is against the standing orders to do so. But I am puzzled at the moment as to what the government is intending to do with their proposals. I have heard all sorts of things, like the government intends to slip off the agenda one proposal that relates to Copyright Amendment Bill (No. 1) but continue on the basis of the other because they think the other is more politically acceptable because the kids and mums out there will all go for cheaper CDs. Well, I say to the government: you have a responsibility to govern in the interests of the country—that is, all of the country—and you should not apply unjustifiable, indefensible processes. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I begin my adjournment speech tonight, not by dignifying Senator Abetz's comments. I can understand his spurious attacks on the Democrats, because he may be feeling a little vulnerable. I rise to actually support his comment that we should not mock the language of others. I should put on the record that the reason I interjected was to save the senator losing the flow of his arguments, as could have been the case had I taken a point of order when he was adversely reflecting on members of the Senate.

speech.para: I rise tonight to debate an issue that is often considered taboo in our community. I begin by commending the funding that is provided under the national illicit drugs strategy, whereby $27.7 million has been allocated to non-government organisations to treat drug problems, focusing on the prevention of illicit substance use abuse amongst young people in particular. I note that the funding applications actually close on 13 July this year.

In Australia we have just had Treatment Works week, which actually coincided with the United Nations International Day against Drug Abuse on 26 June. I take this opportunity to congratulate not only all of those who were involved in that particular program but all of those who are in the front line around Australia in attempting to reduce drug-related harm. I think it takes special people to work in that particular field.

Many social workers, health workers and youth workers have pointed out that criminality hampers education about drug abuse. In fact, one of the few media sources where I have actually heard realistic discussion about drug abuse and indeed the dangers of smoking marijuana and ways of getting help to stop has been Triple J. By freeing up police and legal resources used in the apprehension and punishment of marijuana users, we would have more funds available for health and social services. Illegality of drugs prohibits people from seeking help for addictions. It promotes secrecy, isolation and marginalisation.

As Hazel Hawke has said, `We all need to be a little more honest about drug use'. The use of marijuana in our community is now widespread. Research demonstrates this: almost half of Australia's teenagers have tried marijuana and more than 10 per cent smoke at least once a week. We need to recognise these facts. A 1994 survey even showed that 35 per cent of Young Liberals and 34 per cent of members of federal parliament have, at some stage, smoked marijuana. Had they been caught, of course, it is unlikely that they would actually be here. Since they were arbitrarily lucky enough to escape punishment, I think they owe it to others not as fortunate to be a little more honest about whether or not they support existing laws in relation to drugs.

talk.start.para: —But they didn't inhale.

—I take that interjection—Senator Evans insists they did not inhale. But the possession of a criminal record by those who have inhaled or those who have been caught inhaling is a severe and serious penalty.

speech.para: There are paradoxes and there are inconsistencies in how decision-makers treat different drugs and drug problems. Alcohol and tobacco, which of course are legal drugs, are sold in clearly marked containers specifying the associated health risks, content and purity. Such a system applied to currently illegal drugs possibly would be an integral step towards reducing death by overdose.

The Australian Democrats support harm minimisation over zero tolerance in relation to drug use. We believe drug abuse is a social and a health problem that should be addressed through medical and social services, not through the law and justice systems. We oppose the idea of making those people who choose to use marijuana criminals. We oppose the idea that otherwise law-abiding citizens should be turned into criminals for the personal use of a drug which is, according to the research, in widespread use—and has been in widespread use for many years.

Although there are a number of groups on record who support our policy—the Law Council of Australia, the Australian Parliamentary Group for Drug Law Reform; even the AMA are on record supporting drug reform—the Democrats are the only major political party which has actually been prepared to put out a policy, state our beliefs and identify where we stand on this issue. In addition to the high levels of support for decriminalisation of marijuana by the bodies I have just mentioned, a 1994 poll of federal politicians found that more than half of them were in favour of decriminalisation.

The South Australian government—in 1986—and, of course, the ACT government have relaxed laws in relation to marijuana. In effect, this is decriminalisation for small amounts. A report in May 1998 actually demonstrated that this change in South Australia's marijuana laws did not lead to an increase in use compared with other states. Since the 1970s, report after report has recommended decriminalisation of marijuana.
I recently received a letter from a person in relation to our drugs policy who made some significant points about the existing government laws and policy. I quote:

There can be little argument that abuse of drugs, including alcohol and tobacco, is bad for an individual's health and detrimental to society. However, such harm is exacerbated by making substances illegal and hence, denying users access to health care and treatment programs. Today, despite the millions of dollars spent on law enforcement, drugs are available in nearly every city. In fact, marijuana is more readily available to school-age persons than alcohol—the black market is unlikely to ask for proof of age.
This young person finished off by saying:
End the war on drugs, release the prisoners, educate us.

When reports show that 24 per cent of young people have used marijuana before they turn 16, we are clearly crying out for responsible public health education about this drug, for rational public debate, not only in the community and in the media but in the parliament.

The Democrats are concerned about the fact that half the teenage population are risking criminal records because of the existing drug laws, but we are also concerned about the 10 per cent of teenagers who are smoking more than once a week.

In February 1998 the World Health Organisation concluded that cannabis was safer than alcohol and tobacco. That report, I might add, was unsuccessfully suppressed despite political pressure. We do not pretend that marijuana is a harmless substance. It is relatively benign in comparison to alcohol or heroin, but we do bear in mind that 70 per cent of females aged 14 to 24 years of age and 50 per cent of males usually consume alcohol in quantities which are hazardous or harmful. We are particularly concerned about statistics such as those from 1996 which showed that about 200 15- to 24-year-olds died due to heroin. That was a substantial increase from 1988.

There is a problem in mixing drugs. We know that it is unlikely that you could die from marijuana, except through a secondary source, but mixing drugs is risky. Anecdotal evidence suggests that the marijuana being used today is a great deal more potent than that which may have been commonly available 20 years ago.

So the use of marijuana is not without serious health implications or issues—issues that we feel could be more readily addressed and more easily addressed if the use of marijuana was decriminalised. One of the reasons we support decriminalisation is that we believe there are potential dangers with marijuana use. The responsible use of any drug requires education. In a climate of fear and deception, where marijuana is swept under the table and where any drug debate is considered taboo, these serious health issues are not being properly addressed. A report to the United Nations General Assembly's special session on drugs earlier this year called for a shift in drug control policies from punishment to public health issues. It has been suggested that the global war on drugs is causing more harm than drug abuse itself.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) described the government's Tough on Drugs strategy launched in November last year as a balance between law enforcement and education, treatment and research. I believe that the balance is still far too much in favour of law enforcement. Justice James Woods noted that illicit drugs:
. . . have an enormous impact on corrupting police, particularly police who are otherwise decent, law-abiding and efficient detectives.

Drug issues are highly political, not least because the drug trade is highly lucrative. The drug economy is created by prohibition, which makes the commodity being illegally traded increasingly valuable.

We live on the largest island in the world. We are not going to be successful in shutting off the supply of this drug, but we can do something about demand, particularly abuse, overuse and misuse. We can help people avoid drug abuse. Criminalising them is not the way. Marijuana and other drugs can do great harm—we acknowledge that—but prohibition and punishment is not preventing drug use. We call for a debate on these issues—not only a debate in the parliament but a rational debate in the community and the media. We believe we should be shifting the balance from criminalisation and treating this as a criminal issue to treating it as a social and health issue.

talk.start.para: —It is quite fortuitous that Senator Stott Despoja has tonight raised the issue of drugs, particularly from the demand side, because I want to speak about the supply side. I want to speak about illicit drugs in the community.

speech.para: The fight against drugs should unite governments of all persuasions and not be used for political point scoring. It is a problem that should be tackled as a community, a community made up of people of all races, all walks of life and in fact all political parties. That is the point I wish to discuss tonight—that the fight against illicit drugs in New South Wales is being hampered by the Carr government's half-hearted commitment to work with the federal government, while it is constantly blaming the Commonwealth for the policy failures of the New South Wales government.

For example, how hypocritical is it of Bob Carr and his government to take money confiscated from drug dealers and channel it into other areas? That is precisely what the Carr government has done. Mr Carr's police minister, Mr Whelan, told a recent parliamentary budget estimates committee that the Crime Commission, the body established to seize assets obtained through criminal activities, has taken a record $9.3 million from drug dealers since the legislation was widened last year to include organised crime. That amount is $4 million higher than for any previous year. Bob Carr, who likes to use any and every opportunity to try to deflect attention from his own incompetency, should surely practise what he preaches and use the funds in the war against drugs. After all, they were seized from people who profited from the misery of drugs.

But Mr Whelan told the estimates committee that the proceeds from the sale of confiscated goods will be used to fund anti-crime measures, such as the government's $700,000 campaign to educate the public about the new laws in New South Wales covering the carry ing of knives. While this is a very worthy cause, surely Bob Carr should stick by his principles and use seized drug assets to combat drug use. It is not as if New South Wales is travelling at the front of the pack in combating illicit drugs. Victoria has arrested more heroin dealers in the past two years than New South Wales. New South Wales spends less per capita on law and order than any state other than Queensland and the Australian Capital Territory. The real recurrent expenditure by New South Wales is $194 per head, compared with $210 for Victoria, $218 for Western Australia, $213 for South Australia and $195 for Tasmania. These are not the Commonwealth's figures. These are the figures published by the steering committee for the review of Commonwealth-state service provision. It is just another example of how the Carr government is failing the people of New South Wales.

Obviously, Mr Carr's short-term memory problems have precluded him from acknowledging the government's Tough on Drugs strategy. That initiative was initially costed at $87.5 million over three years when it was announced last year, but such is the Commonwealth's commitment to the strategy that in this year's budget the funding was lifted to $215 million over five years.

Just what a menace illicit drugs are can be gleaned from statistics released by the Alcohol and Other Drugs Council of Australia. It found that in 1996 there were 634 heroin related deaths in Australia; up to 66 per cent of prisoners reported they were under the influence of alcohol or drugs when they committed their major crimes; more than 25 per cent of prisoners have a major drug problem; up to 80 per cent of property crime in New South Wales is drug related; illicit drugs are associated with more than 40,500 hospital bed days in Australia each year; on any given day specialist agencies provide residential or counselling services to more than 9,000 illicit drug users; and spending on illicit drugs amounts to some $57 billion a year.

The Commonwealth is seriously committed to this fight, which is why it has increased spending to battle drugs. The additional spending will be broken into $50 million over four years for ways to address the use of drugs. This includes $21 million to strengthen the capacity of non-government treatment services to better assist those people with drug addiction and to help break the cycle of drug dependency and criminal behaviour; $4.36 million to evaluate and promote best practice in the treatment of illicit drug dependence; $15.5 million for a community-wide education and information campaign to discourage a new generation of drug users and addicts; and, $3.5 million to develop a strategic early warning system to alert governments to emerging drug problems. On top of this, there will be $50 million spent to find ways of tackling the supply side of the drug trade.

Once again, Bob Carr's selective memory was in evidence when all these initiatives were announced. He seemed to forget that the Commonwealth has already funded three strike force teams, and three strike force teams are based in New South Wales. The funding from the Commonwealth for strike force teams is $15.5 million, more than the funds for the new strike force teams announced in the latest round of announcements for the drug strategy.

The Commonwealth provided the funds for these new strike force teams because it recognises Sydney is a major gateway for the importation of drugs. In fact, the establishment of strike force teams could have led to calls from other states that they were being disadvantaged, but it did not because they recognised that the Commonwealth's strategy against drugs is not about winning votes but about saving lives and restoring shattered hopes.

Bob Carr also likes to claim that the Commonwealth has cut expenditure for Australian Customs in its drug detection activities. Again, he is making up exaggerated stories to try to create a smokescreen to hide his own government's failures in the battle against drugs. The reality is that, between 1991 and 1995, the number of personnel in Customs fell by more than 700. Those years—1991 to 1995—were, of course, years of the Labor government but, under the coalition, things have steadily improved. In fact, Customs resources have been particularly targeted towards areas where they are likely to be of greatest benefit.

For example, in the 1996 budget, $26 million was provided over three years for technology specifically designed to aid in drug detection and interception. The coalition has also upgraded the Customs marine fleet, which enables the department to undertake surveillance up to 300 nautical miles off the coast, and there has been increased funding to match the increase in passenger movements in and out of Australia.

But it is in the area of heroin seizures that the result is most spectacular. In 1996 to 1997, Customs seized $40.6 million worth, compared with $15.4 million worth the previous year. The $40 million figure represents just under 170 kilos of seized heroin.

Let us look at what that means in terms of use: 300 grams of heroin represents 6,000 hits, or one hit for every student in 10 large high schools; one kilo represents 20,000 hits, or 10 hits for every professional football player in Australia; five kilos represents 100,000 hits, or one hit for everyone who might go to an Australian Rules grand final at the MCG; 32 kilos, the amount seized in one haul in 1997, represents 650,000 hits, or one hit for every person in the Northern Territory and Tasmania; and, 78 kilos, the amount seized in Sydney in May 1997, represents one hit for every household in Sydney, or one hit for every 15- to 19-year-old person in Australia.

It is clear then just what an impact the seizure of 170 kilos has on the illicit drug market, but still Bob Carr cannot bring himself to be positive. Bob Carr must stop his constant whine and whinge routine and, instead of his fatuous excuses, get stuck into the battle against drugs. His commitment seems to waiver.

For instance, how can you be serious about the battle against drugs when you have police stations, such as that at Canterbury in Sydney, advising that they will be open only from nine to five on normal business days? Does Mr Carr really think that they are the only hours in which traffickers traffic? Instead of looking for cheap shots, Mr Carr should be directing his energy and attention to a positive and constructive approach to combating the flow of drugs into this country.

The Commonwealth has already clearly spelt out its commitment to this objective through strategies, policing and funding. It is time Bob Carr did the same. The deaths of 634 Australians a year from heroin, most of them tragically young, should wake us all up to see that the problem is too important and too urgent to be reduced to the level of political tit for tat.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism, upon notice, on 17 April 1998:

question.para: (1) Given that nine departments have now answered in full the questions placed on notice on 16 October 1997 (questions on notice 902-916, Senate Notice Paper of 21 October 1997) relating to qualitative or quantitative research, on what basis was it decided that the department would not authorise the money, time and effort involved to assemble the information required to provide an answer to the question.
(2) What qualitative or quantitative research has been undertaken by the department and its agencies since 3 March 1996.
(3) (a) What was the nature of the research undertaken (sample sizes, questionnaire length, evaluation); and (b) to whom were the results of the research available.
(4) In each instance, which firm or firms have been engaged to undertake this work.
(5) In each instance, what has been the cost of the work undertaken.
